title: 104_hr851
content:
The "Rural Telemedicine Act of 1995" is established to create a project for rural telemedicine. The "Rural Telemedicine Act of 1995" establishes up to 10 pilot projects to investigate the use of rural health care provider telemedicine networks for physician consultative services under Medicare in rural areas. A rural health care provider telemedicine network is defined as a network of providers serving physicians, clinics, and nontertiary care providers in rural areas. A rural health care provider telemedicine network is a network of providers serving physicians, clinics, and nontertiary care providers in a rural area designated as a health professional shortage area or an underserved rural area. The text chunk "SEC. 3. MEDICARE PAYMENT FOR PARTICIPANTS." is a concise statement regarding Medicare payment for participants. The Secretary will make payments from the Federal Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund for physicians' services in rural areas, regardless of location, under projects established by this Act. The methodology for determining payment amounts will be based on available funds. The consultation for physician services in rural areas will be paid from the Federal Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund. The Secretary will establish a methodology for determining payment amounts based on available funds, including payment for signal transmission facilities. Payments can also be made for services provided by nonphysician providers. SEC. 4. ELIGIBILITY OF NETWORKS. Networks eligible for pilot projects must submit an application to the Secretary and agree to provide necessary information. The term "rural area" is defined in the Social Security Act.

SEC. 5. CRITERIA FOR SELECTING PARTICIPANTS. SEC. 5. CRITERIA FOR SELECTING PARTICIPANTS. The Secretary will prioritize networks that facilitate consultations between patients and specialists through detailed data transmission. Existing networks can also participate in the pilot projects. The Secretary will submit an interim report to Congress within 24 months of making payments for pilot project services, detailing participating projects and networks, expenses, and patient numbers. A final report will be submitted within 1 year after project termination, analyzing cost-effectiveness, success in providing specialist consultations in rural areas, and impact on patient access to higher quality care. The Secretary will provide an analysis of the projects' cost-effectiveness, impact on patient care quality, and recommendations for changes in the Medicare program related to telemedicine. Authorization of appropriations from the Federal Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund for a total of $51,000,000 for a demonstration project under this Act, with up to $1,000,000 allocated for administrative purposes.
